channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for IA
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for IA

  • Description: RESPONDER RESPONDED TO THE SPILL WEARING ALL PROPPER PPE, USING THE CORROSIVE RESPONSE SHEET, RESPONDER RESPONDED TO THE SPILL. RESPONDER CONTAINED THE SPILL AND USING THE DECISON TREE AND THE CORROSIVE RESPONSE SHEET. THEN PROCESSED THE SPILL WITH WASTED DISPOSAL CHART IN THE DMP AREA

item.title: Report E-2024020006
item.description:
Report E-2024020006

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-05T15:13:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-30
  • City: DAVENPORT
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver was offloading at the facility at approximately 1000 and noticed liquid coming from pump manifold. The driver immediately stopped pumping and got a closer look and found a crack in the manifold. This caused a release of less than 1 gallon onto the containment pad. The material was immediately wiped up and disposed of per the regulations.

item.title: Report X-2024010075
item.description:
Report X-2024010075

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-06T18:12:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-23
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 12-23-2023 a CN transportation employee observed liquid dripping from the bottom outlet valve cap during routing work operations at the CN Waterloo Yard in Waterloo, IA. The employee notified the Yard Supervisor who then initiated an emergency response from the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The responding DG Officer observed liquid dripping from the BOV cap which was found to be tool tight (could not turn by hand). The shipper's security seal was not found. BOV handle was in the fully closed position. It was determined that there was a failure in the sealing surface of the valve seat to include a defective or missing BOV gasket. The BOV handle was cycled several times from the closed to open position to ensure there was no foreign material trapped in the valve seat that would prevent a proper seal. The cap was then removed, and the valve was monitored for 10 minutes for any continued leakage. There was no longer any leakage from the valve at this point. An inspection of the BOV cap gasket was performed and revealed it to be very stiff allowing the product to leak past the gasket. The BOV gasket was replaced, and the cap re-installed utilizing a 24" pipe wrench.
